Survivors of disaster, violence, or other traumas often feel out of control. eCourage will help you decide on simple positive actions that can help strengthen your sense of control.
eCourage can help you calm your body and mind, get support from others, lift your mood, support others as well as yourself, and move towards wise use of alcohol or drugs.
eCourage doesn\'t impose any requirements. You set your own goals and choose the means that help you most. We\'re simply here to help!
Your Coach is a friend or family member who connects with you and helps monitor your progress
Doing Positive Activities can slowly make us feel more positive about life, that life is worth living.
Positive activities are an important part of feeling like life is worth living.
It is easy for the enjoyable aspects of life to get lost or forgotten, because of traumatic stress and sadness.
However, the less and less we engage in doing things that make us feel good,the more and more the stress and sadness can take over.
Integrating Positive Activities back into daily life after trauma can, over time, increase positive feelings and decrease feels like sadness and despair.
You might think that you have to do BIG things to feel these effects but doing even small things can be helpful.
It’s important to remember that these activities don’t have to take a lot of time! Start Small!

Trying to make sense of what happened is part of the natural human response to trauma. Most people spend a lot of time thinking about what happened, why it happened, and what it means for the future.
When bad things happen, we often find ourselves thinking a lot. In fact, traumatic events can weaken our confidence in ourselves, change our view of others, and make us worry.
How you think - what you say to yourself about what happened or is happening - will affect your mood and emotions, how you cope with your challenges, and how effectively you build your life.
Being your own friend means talking to yourself in a way that strengthens you, helps you remain positive, and keeps you stay focused on the path forward.

Helpful thoughts can help you feel in control and able to cope. For example, thoughts like “I’ve come through other things, I can come through this too” or “Things will get better with time” or “I’ve just got to take things slowly, one day at a time.”
It is important for you to become more aware of what you are saying to yourself, and to gradually replace your negative self-talk with thoughts that help your recovery.

It’s not that you’re wrong to think in any particular way. Your beliefs make sense in terms of what has happened to you. But the goal here is to help you think about things in ways that help you feel more calm and positive.
Beliefs and Judgments are not the same things as “facts.” They are opinions, judgments, and interpretations that could be true or not true, exaggerated or realistic, and helpful or unhelpful.

Many people feeling strong stress often wonder, “Am I going crazy?” This is a thought or belief, not a fact. It is not a fact that you’re going crazy. There is nothing crazy about having uncontrollable distress and upsetting thoughts after trauma; they happen to almost everyone.
Many people think that having trouble coping with trauma means that they’re “weak.” But actually many strong, competent people have very painful reactions to stress.

The more you tell yourself that you’re crazy or weak, the more you feel bad. In reverse, if you tell yourself that these reactions are a normal part of getting over a trauma, and that you can learn ways to help yourself cope with these reactions, you may feel less bad.
We want to help you rethink your upsetting beliefs and replace unhelpful self-talk with helpful self-talk that helps you feel stronger and more in control.
